awd_titl_txt: Identification and Characterization of Transcription Factors Regulating Carotenoid Pigmentation During Mimulus Flower Development
awd_abstract_narration:
Carotenoids are yellow, orange, and red pigments that contribute to the beautiful colors and nutritive value of many flowers (e.g., daffodils, daylilies, sunflowers) and fruits (e.g., oranges, tomatoes, mangos). They serve an important function in the ecology and evolution of plants as visual pigments to attract animals for pollination and seed dispersal. The tremendous diversity of carotenoid pigmentation patterns found in flowers and fruits is primarily determined by regulatory genes that control when and where the carotenoid pigments are produced. However, little is known about the identity and function of these regulatory genes. This study employs a new plant genetic model system, monkeyflowers, to identify carotenoid-regulating genes and to characterize their function. The discovery and characterization of these regulatory genes are crucial to understanding how carotenoid production is controlled during flower development and how carotenoid-based flower color variation is generated during evolution. From a practical perspective, because carotenoids are also essential components of human diets as precursors for vitamin A biosynthesis, the regulatory genes discovered in this study have the potential for high translational impact in plant breeding to enhance carotenoid production in crop plants. The plant materials will be incorporated into a live plant exhibit at the University of Connecticut to demonstrate concepts of genetics and evolution for student and public education. Furthermore, the flower images, pollination videos, and interactive, multimedia illustrations resulting from this project will be developed into a new Plant Biology section on the nationally and internationally recognized Learn.Genetics website as online educational resources. 

This study leverages recently developed genomic resources, stable transgenic tools, and chemically induced mutants of monkeyflowers (Mimulus) to identify and characterize transcription factors that regulate flower carotenoid pigmentation. Results from preliminary work in the PIs laboratory allows the formulation of the central hypothesis: a transcriptional regulatory complex, containing at least an R2R3-MYB and a tetratricopeptide repeat (TPR) protein, directly activates carotenoid biosynthetic genes during flower development in Mimulus, and differential expression of the regulatory genes contributes to pigment pattern variation between species. In this proposed project, additional components of the transcriptional regulatory complex will be identified by bulk segregant analysis of another non-allelic mutant and by yeast two-hybrid screening using the MYB and TPR proteins as baits. The functional mechanisms of the MYB and TPR genes in the regulation of carotenoid pigmentation will be determined by protein-protein and protein-DNA interaction assays. The role of these regulatory genes in producing flower color variation will be examined by gene expression analysis and transgenic experiments in Mimulus species that display distinct carotenoid pigmentation patterns.

por.por_cntn:
Carotenoids are yellow, orange, and red pigments that contribute to the beautiful colors and color patterns of many flowers (e.g., sunflowers, daffodils, tulips, daylilies). The tremendous diversity of floral carotenoid pigmentation patterns is primarily determined by regulatory genes that control when and where these pigments are produced. However, very little is known about the identity and function of these regulatory genes. The primary outcomes of this project are the discovery and functional characterization of four regulatory genes of carotenoid biosynthesis. These genes were identified by analyzing chemically induced flower mutants of the monkeyflower species Mimulus lewisii and M. verbenaceus. Among the four genes, two encode typical R2R3-MYB transcription factors that activate the expression of other genes (e.g., carotenoid biosynthetic genes); one encodes a large TPR protein that is required for proper development of chromoplasts, the subcellular organelles that store carotenoids; the other encodes a DICER-like protein required for small RNA biogenesis. These results suggest that carotenoid pigmentation in flowers is regulated by an intricate network of transcription factors, small RNAs, and organelle-to-nucleus retrograde signaling pathways.

Notably, we employed CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing in M. lewisii for the first time and generated multiple independent mutants of the DICER-like gene that closely resemble the original chemically induced mutant in flower phenotype. These results demonstrate that CRISPR-Cas9 mediated genome editing can be a powerful tool in this emerging model system (i.e., monkeyflowers), where we can study the genetics and developmental biology of many ecologically important plant traits that are infeasible to study using the conventional plant genetic model system, Arabidopsis.

In addition to characterizing flower mutants, we have also taken a genetic mapping approach to identity genes underlying natural variation between closely related monkeyflower species. In particular, we mapped YELLOW UPPER, a classical “speciation” gene that controls the presence vs. absence of yellow carotenoid pigments in the flower petals and underlie pollinator shift between bumblebee-pollinated Mimulus lewisii and hummingbird-pollinated M. cardinalis, to a very small genomic region, making the cloning of this long-sought speciation gene within easy reach.

Taken together, results from this project provide the fundamental information on how the biosynthesis of carotenoids, a major type of plant pigments, are regulated in flowers, and provide the "toolkit" genes to understand the genetic and molecular basis of natural flower color variation as well as targets for genetic engineering to improve carotenoid production in crop plants.

Another important outcome from this project is the development of a dozen educational modules on “Flowering Plants and Their Pollinators” on the internationally recognized "Learn.Genetics" website. This is a series of online educational modules targeted to students at multiple levels, such as plant pollination for younger students up through gene regulation and transcription factors for upper high school and university students. Furthermore, this project has contributed to the training and professional development of one postdoctoral researcher, one graduate student and four undergraduate students in the PI’s laboratory. Both the postdoc and the graduate student had an ecology/evolutionary biology background and have learned a great deal of developmental genetics through this project. This combination of skills in both ecology/evolution and developmental genetics enables them to occupy a unique position in the wide-open niche of using developmental genetics tools to attack evolutionary questions.
